editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: And to the Right Wor≈øhipfull Sir Iohn Swi ‚Ä¢ erton and Sir Thomas Hayes Knights and Aldermen, mo≈øt True and honourable affectors of Mu≈øicke.
div.p:
AS I doe account it a great portion of happines to haue receiu'd fir≈øt In≈øtructions, Exerci≈øe, and Encouragement of my Studies in this Auncient and mo≈øt Famous City: So am I thereby bound, and doe (willingly) endeuour my be≈øt pa ‚Ä¢ t and power, both to te≈øtifie and augment the Life and Honour of this Liberall Science which I
pro ‚Ä¢ e≈ø≈øe, to the benefit of all Students therein, and the contentment of all Affectors thereof in this my natiue Country, and e≈øpecially in this the Metropolis thereof, which gaue fir≈øt life and breaching to my poore Endeauours. And herein I mu≈øt, and doe acknowledge it as a ≈øingular helpe and benefit, that I haue receiu'd diuers In≈øtructions, Re≈øolutions, and Confirmations of ≈øundry Points, and Praecepts in our Art, from the Mu≈øicke Readers of that mo≈øt famous Colledge, founded and erected by the euer prai≈øeworthie, and iu≈øtly renown'd Senator Sr. Thomas Gre≈øham; who bearing his neuer dying Name, as a Prae≈øident and Patterne to his Co-Citizens, to ≈øhew them the right way to aeternize their names to future po≈øteritie, by being kinde Nur≈øing Fathers to good Literature, Reu ‚Ä¢ ed the liberall Arts and Sciences, e≈øpecially the Mathematickes, which were ≈øomewhat neglected euen in the Vniuer≈øities; and endowed them with ≈øuch Maintenance and exhibition, that (their worldly wants being more then meanly ≈øupply'd) they haue and doe continually ≈øtriue with highe≈øt Art and Indu≈øtry, ≈øo to explaine them to the world by way of Lecture, and otherwi≈øe, that much good from thence redoundeth to many de≈øirous of tho≈øe Knowledges, and more and more will, as time and occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerue. What fruits my ≈øelfe in particular haue receiu'd
by that one particular Lecture of Mu≈øicke (whereof I was an vnworthie Auditor) I dutifully acknowledge to haue proceeded from that Colledge; and doe heere Commende and Dedicate them to your Wor≈øhipps, Who are Vi≈øitors and Guardians of that mo≈øt famous Foundation, from whence I haue receiu'd ≈øuch benefit in the≈øe my ≈øtudies. For as I haue beene encouraged by your Noblenes to trauaile in the≈øe Studies, ≈øo by Dutie they belong to You, from whome they had their Animation. May it therefore plea≈øe your Wor≈øhips to accept this my Di≈øcour≈øe of Mu≈øicke with ≈øome Harmonicall Examples thereof, as a Simple Sacrifice, in part of that deuotion and ≈øeruice which I owe, vpon promi≈øe and full intendment by your wonted goodnes and a≈øi≈øtance, to ≈øearch for Richer and riper Di≈øcoueries in this Mu≈øicall Continent. So wi≈øhing the long Continuance of your carefull Loue, and louing Care to al good Learning, e≈øpecially to Mu≈øicke, the earthly Solace of Mans Soule, I euer Remaine

closer.signed: The Honourer, and ≈øincere Affector of your Approued good Mindes Thomas Rauen≈øcroft.

div.head: Apologie.
div.p: PLutarch in his Booke of Mu≈øicke ≈øaith, that Pherecrates the Comicall Poet pre≈øented Mu≈øicke in forme and habite of a Woman, her body pitteou≈øly ≈øcourged and mangled; Iu≈øtice demaunding the rea≈øon, ≈øhe in her complaint made an≈øwere, that Melanipides, Cyne≈øias, Phrynis, and Timotheus had through certaine vncertaine Opinions and Changes, wrought her ≈øo much woe.

If Pherecrates had now liued, well and truely might he haue haue pre≈øented herTerent. Pannis annis
que ob≈øitam, with ≈øcarce Ligatures left to pre≈øerue the compacture of her Body, ≈øo much is ≈øhe wrong'd, dilac ‚Ä¢ rated, di≈ømembred, and di≈øioynted in the≈øe our daies; ≈øhe ≈øcarcely hath Forme or Habite left, but e'ne as a Sceleton, retaines onely a ≈øhape, or ≈øhadowe, of what ≈øhe was in her former purity.

Now may ≈øhe ≈øit complayning, O woe is me, that was ordain'd for the welfare of all vertue in Man; O woe is me, that to whome I brought ≈øo much goodne≈ø≈øe, by him I ≈øhould be vilified, and ≈øo ill intreated; O woe is me, that for whome, and for who≈øe be≈øt good I ordain'd Lawes and Praecepts, by him, and onely him, I ≈øhould be thus abu≈ø'd, my Lawes violated, my Precepts reiected, and my ≈øelfe made a laughing ≈øtocke; O woe is me, that e're I was, or did ≈øo much good for him that ≈øets ≈øo light by me.

And (if euer) this braine-≈øicke Age wherein we liue, may be≈øt te≈øtifie her mi≈øery; for neither Her ≈øelfe, nor her Lawes are regarded euen of her Children, but mo≈øt led by their ≈øtragling pa≈ø≈øions runne after their owne rebellious Imaginations; which doth breed a mi≈øery of mi≈øeries vnto Her, great griefe and ≈øorrow to her true borne Children, and to all, a ba≈øe wretched E≈øtimation, a≈øwell among≈øt tho≈øe who know her Eminencie, as tho≈øe who neuer knew Her, nor any other vertue.

And if we ≈øhall finde (as certainely finde we ≈øhall) in one member of Her, in one little part of her Praecepts, ≈øo many erroneous and repugnant Ab≈øurdities committed, what ≈øhould we meete with, if we did ≈øearch into her whole Body? ≈øurely ≈øuch a contumelious In≈øurrection, that either for Ignorance or ≈øhame in ≈øo much wronging Her, we mu≈øt ≈øtand ob≈øtinate, and ≈øet Her at defiance, or with peaceable vnder≈øtanding ≈øubmit our≈øelues to Her Cen≈øure, checking our
Emperour they e≈øteeme Learning and all Vertue to be the Bane and plague of a Common wealth: And yet (for≈øooth) the≈øe Archidamu≈øes will ≈øeeme to countenance and entertaine Mu≈øi ‚Ä¢ ks Profe≈ø≈øors; But alas it is vpon Colour and Praetext, to make ≈øhew vnto the world that there is in them a Mu≈øicall Genius, and a religious di≈øpo≈øition; they make this their vertue, to ≈øhadow ≈øuch inhumane de≈øires, for the better accompli≈øhing of their priuate ends. And when their humours are to be be≈øotted with the Soule-raui≈øhing plea≈øure and content of melodious Harmony, they ≈øeeke either by di≈ø≈øembling Commendations, or gro≈ø≈øe Flattery, or the like, (by any ordinary capacity quickly conceiued) to grieue and di≈øcontent tho≈øe outwardly, who affoord them delight, and contentment inwardly.

lg.l: THe ten-fold Orbes of Heauen are ≈øaid to moue
By Mu≈øicke; for they make Harmonious din:
And all the Powres ≈øubordinate aboue
Spend Time, nay, ≈øpend Aeternity therein.
If Mu≈øicke then, moue all that All doth moue;
That's not compriz'd in ALL that ≈øpights her State:
If not in ALL, it's nought; which who doth loue
is wor≈øe then nought, to loue what Heau'n doth hate:
For, NOVGHT is nothing; ≈øith it was not made

Like God, her goodne≈ø≈øe is ≈øurmounting THOVGHT!
But no man is ≈øo ill that hath no good;

A Bea≈øt? O no: A Mon≈øter? neither. Then

FORMES, E≈ø≈øence giue to Man, Bea≈øt, Fi≈øh, & Fowle;

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: MU≈øicke in ancient times, was held in as great E≈øtimation, Reuerence, and Honour, by the Be≈øt vnder≈øtandings and Noble≈øt Bloods, as any Science Liberall what≈øoeuer. The Graue Philo≈øophers reputed it an Inuention of the Gods, which they had be≈øtowed on Men, to make them better conditioned, then bare Nature affoorded: And the Wi≈øe Grecians therefore educated their children in it, that by meanes of it, they might temper their mindes, and fully ≈øettle therein, the Vertues of Mode≈øtie and Hone≈øty: and, (in a word) all of worth euer held it, a very Direct and Nece≈ø≈øary cour≈øe, for the be≈øt In≈øtitution of Life, and Correction of ill manners.

The Cau≈øes then of that Di≈ørepute, and ouer lowe E≈øtimation, which Mu≈øicke in the≈øe dayes, (for the mo≈øt part) ≈øu≈øtaines, and whether they proceed from Corruptions of Nature, or Art, or both, as long ≈øince I began to meruaile at, ≈øo had I now vttered ≈øome ob≈øeruations thereabout, had not coun≈øaile, and di≈øcretion per≈øwaded me a while for a further exact ≈øuruay.

I had then (amid≈øt other things) vnfolded on the one ≈øide, both the Naturall, and al≈øo the Politick Affector and
Entert ‚Ä¢ yner of our Art, and on the other ≈øide, the ≈øtrange imbecillity of our Profe≈ø≈øors, a great part of them Profe≈øt Generall M ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øters, able (they will vndertake) fully to teach both precepts and Practi≈øe of our Art, in one poore yeare, (or le≈ø≈øe if you will:) and yet (≈øpoken it ≈øhall be without offence) the mo≈øt of them, not well vnder≈øtanding the very Nature of a Sound, or the Difference of P. operties, the Distinction of Tones, the Diui≈øion of Numbers and Mea≈øures, the inaequalitie of Proportions, nay, ≈øcar≈øe Defining the nature of that In≈øtrument, Mai≈øters whereof they profe≈ø≈øe them≈øelues to be.

I had likewi≈øe poynted at ≈øome other abu≈øes, committed and ≈øuffered by Mu≈øicks Profe≈ø≈øors, as well in Eccle≈øia≈øticke as Common Seruice, whereby the one, findes his Due Right empay ‚Ä¢ ed; & the other, his E≈øtimation; and both, their Abilities.

As for tho≈øe common kinde Practitioners, (truly ycleped Min≈øtrells, though our City makes Mu≈øitians of them) who making account for≈øooth to doe the Art Honour, now in the≈øe daies of the ill opinion, and ≈ømall credit it beares, haue (fairely) brought it downe from a cheife Liberall Science, to the ba≈øe≈øt almo≈øt of Mechanick Functions: I make no que≈øtion, but in good time it may returne vpon their owne necks, and their De≈øert be rewarded, as Statute in that ca≈øe hath already (mo≈øt worthily) prouided.

Be≈øides, I ≈øuppo≈øe I ≈øhould hardly haue omitted the Beleefe (whereof I finde ≈øome Aery or In≈øtrumentall Compo≈øers and Practitioners to be) concerning certaine Vices, which their Ignorance is per≈øwaded, our Art receiues helpe by, how di≈øagreeing ≈øoeuer, both to Nature and
‚Ä¢ ea≈øon, which is the ≈øoule of all Arts.

And then for amends of all, I ≈øhould at la≈øt, haue affoorded ≈øomewhat in the generall precepts, both of Plaine, and Mea≈øurable Mu≈øick, in the many Diuer≈øities, which the Nature of Compo≈øitions giue vs, from the very originall of them, to
that excellencie, wherein the Art is now to be found, and in divers other particulars tending to the ≈øame effect.

But now in the meane time, let the Affector ≈øhew his Di≈øpo≈øition, and the Profe≈øsor his Art, to both whome I promi≈øe, that when e're I proceed in it, I will be free and impartiall, as Rule and Rea≈øon onely giues me, laying my Ob≈øeruations, and ≈øo de≈øiring (if it may be) the re≈øtitution of our Science, to Due, and ancient Honour.

And till then (if at all they loue the Art) they ≈øhall well accept of my good will, and (with me) take in good worth, the≈øe various Sprightfull, Delightfull Harmonies, which now I bring them. Their Compo≈øure I dare warrant, 'tis not onely of Ayre, made for ≈øome ≈ømall tickling of the outward Sence alone, but a great deale more ≈øolide, and ≈øweetly vnited to Number, Mea≈øures, and Nature of the Ditty. The earne≈øt affections which a man hath, in the v≈øe of ≈øuch Recreations as they are made for, are ≈øo fully expre≈øt in them, for Tact, Prolation, and Diminution, that not onely the Ignorant Eare mu≈øt needs be plea≈øed with them, for their Variety of ≈øweet Stray ‚Ä¢ es, and the Humorous Fanta≈øtick eare ≈øati≈øfied, in the Iocundity of their many Changes, but al≈øo the Iudicious hearer will finde that in them, which pa≈ø≈øes the Outward ≈øence, & ≈øtrikes a rare delight of Pa≈ø≈øion vpon the Mind it ≈øelfe, that attends them.

I will take ≈øo much Iudgement vpon me, as to affirme, I finde a great part of them ≈øo, though (without any tryall) the very Naming of tho≈øe two Worthies in their Art, and Times, (and e≈øpecially in the≈øe kinds) who fir≈øt Compo≈øed that part I now ≈øpeake of, is warrant inough for ≈øuch a Beleefe of them Mai≈øter Edward Pearce the fir≈øt, ≈øometimes Mai≈øter of the Children of Saint Paules in London, and there my Mai≈øter, a man of ≈øingular eminency in his Profe≈ø≈øion, both in the Educating of Children for the ordering of the Voyce ≈øo, as the Quality might afterward credit him and preferre
them: And al≈øo in tho≈øe his Compo≈øitions to the Lute, whereof, the world enioyes many, (as from the Mai≈øter of that In≈øtrument) together with his skilfull In≈øtructions for other In≈øtruments too, as his fruits can beare him witne≈ø≈øe.

The ≈øecond I name, as partner in this worke, is Mai≈øter Iohn Bennet, a Gentleman admirable for all kindes of Compo≈øures, either in Art, or Ayre, Simple or Mixt, of what Nature ≈øoeuer. I can ea≈øily beleeue he had ≈øom what more then Art, euen ≈øome Naturall in≈øtinct or Better In≈øpiration, by which, in all his workes, the very life of that Pa≈ø≈øion, which the Ditty ≈øounded, is ≈øo truely expre≈øt, as if he had mea≈øured it alone by his owne Soule, and inuented no other Harmony, then his owne ≈øen≈øible feeling in that Affection did affoord him.

As for this little worke, and the Diuer≈øities therein, they appertayne all, to the common Recreations that men take, and therein vtter that Pa≈ø≈øion which men di≈øcouer in the v≈øe of th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe Recreations: As are
All which are here as liuely Characteriz'd, as euer were any of the kind yet among vs, withall Mea≈øure, and Rule to Art appertayning.

HHunting & Hawking haue the fir≈øt place, as the mo≈øt gener ‚Ä¢ us and worthy kindes of Recreations. In the performance of both which, ≈øuch are the Times, Numbers, and Mea≈øures, ob≈øeruable, not in Man alone that v≈øes the Pa≈øtime, but euen in the Creatures al≈øo, that either make the Game, or pur≈øue it,
as being duely Compo≈øed, beget an excellent Harmony, and require the Singers skill to vtter them, as if he were then abroad at the performing of them.

THe next we pre≈øent is Dauncing, but that with ≈øome difference from the common Exerci≈øe now a daies of it, in our Maskes and Reuells: As not grounded on the Dauncing of Mea≈øures, and accordingly bound to ≈øome particular Rules and Numbers, proper to the Nature of that Daunce onely, which then is afoot: But fa≈øhioned like tho≈øe Antique Daunces, which the Poets would haue vs beleeue, the Fayries, and the Satyres, and tho≈øe other R ‚Ä¢ rall Natures frequented, and hauing in them, much more variety and change then any other Compo≈øition, and withall ≈øo expre≈ø≈øing our imperfect Moods and Mea≈øures, for their Tact, Prolation, and Diminution, that in ≈øinging, cunningly and Sprightfully to re≈øemble them, mu≈øt needs giue the performance high commendation, and the Hearer the mo≈øt plea≈øing delight that may be.

DRinking is our fourth Recreation. For ≈øo 'tis become (at lea≈øt, if not the fir≈øt) by the v≈øe & Delight that men now take in it, and ≈øo, for their ≈øakes, I am content now to terme it. And among all the re≈øt, for theirs E≈øpecially, that in the Aery part of our Faculty, for want of Skill and Rea≈øon in that which they performe, ≈øet their Strength and Spirits to ≈øearch it out of the other Elements, chiefely out of tho≈øe two, that the Ayre is enuironed with, Fire and Water, well compo≈ø'd and Brew'd together, wherein they are re≈øolued to grow exceeding skilfull, or el≈øe it ≈øhal co≈øt their Braines a fiering, and their Bowells a drowning. The Earth indeed they looke lea≈øt after, t'is ba≈øe that they account, and for Mechanick Spirits to runne ≈øo lowe, The Note they ≈øing

div.head: The Definitions and Diui≈øions of Moode, Time, & Prolation in Mea≈øurable Mu≈øick.
div.p:
MEn≈øurabilis Mu≈øice is defined to be a Harmony of diuers ≈øortes of Sounds, expre≈øt by certaine Characters or Figures called Notes, di≈øcribd on Lines & Spaces, different in Name, E≈ø≈øence, Forme, Quantity, and Quality, which are ≈øung by a Mea≈øure of Time; or as
‚Ä¢ o: Dun≈øtable Men≈øurabilis, Mu≈øicae cap. 1. Io: Dun≈øtable, Io: Nucius mu≈øica Poetica cap. 1. the man whome Ioan. Nucius in his Poeticall Mu≈øicke (and diuers others) affirme to be the fir≈øt that inuented Compo≈øition) ≈øaith, it hath his beginning at an Vnite, and increa≈øeth vpward by two and by three infinitely, and from the highe≈øt decrea≈øeth in like manner downe againe to an Vnite.
Mea≈øure in this Science is a Quantity of the length and ≈øhortnes of Time, either by Naturall ≈øounds pronounced by Voice, or by Artificiall, vpon In≈øtruments.

Of this Mu≈øick, Franchinus de Coloni√¢ was the fir≈øt Inuentor; and to guide our knowledge the better, ob≈øeruing the ≈øame cour≈øe that Guid ‚Ä¢ Ar ‚Ä¢ tinus did, (who in≈øtituted the forme of Plaine, or Simple Mu≈øick) He made Scales or Tables, in the which all things pertaining to the diui≈øion of Perfect and Imperfect Mea≈øures are contained, and by the which we may by degree attaine to the perfection of this Knowledge.

The Scales or Tables (by him in≈øtituted) of diuers are vulgarly termed Moodes, by ≈øome of better vnder≈øtanding, Mea≈øures; and con≈øi≈øt of Notes, Pau≈øes, Degrees, Signes, Perfection, and Imperfection.

div.head: Of Notes.
div.p: A Note is a Signe, or Character reprae≈øenting either a Naturall, or Artificiall Sound: and it is two fold;

Simple Notes (Like Nowne Sub≈øtantiues) require none other to be ioyned with them, to ≈øhew their ≈øignes, or ≈øignifications; of which there are 8. Glareanus Dodecachod. lib. 3. cap. 4. the fir≈øt fiue are cal'd E≈ø≈øentiall the la≈øt 3. Colaterall. 1. Large, 2. Long. 3. Breue 4. Semibreue. 5. Minime. 6. Crotchet. 7. Quauer. 8. Semiquauer.

Compound Notes (Like Nowne Adiectiues) cannot ≈øtand by them≈øelues, but require another to be ioyned with them to ≈øhew their ≈øignes and ≈øignifications; & ari≈øe from the 4. fir≈øt ≈øimple Notes. Larg, Long, Breue, & Semibreue; which being fitly conioyn'd one with another, we terme Ligatures; of which, tho≈øe that are with 10: Dunst. Mu≈ø. cap. 12. plikes or ≈øtrokes in Quadrate formes are called Rectes,
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
‚Ä¢ ho≈øe that are by crooked ones 10: Dunst. Mu≈ø. cap. 12. Obliques,
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ either a≈øcending or de≈øcending; in the Charactering of which, that at the beginning, that in the Middle, and that at the latter end mu≈øt ≈øpecially be ob≈øerued.

For en≈øamples, I refer all to tho≈øe forraine Authors, that haue at large di≈øcour≈øt of the particular praeceps of this part of Mu≈øicke: but dome≈øtically to The: Mor: lib. 1. fol. 9. 10. 11. Ma≈øter Tho: Morley who will ≈øati≈ø≈øye any curious ob≈øeruer.

The≈øe Ligatures were inuented for two re≈øpects: 1. for the Ditties ≈øake 2. (without Ditty) for breuity of Pricking. But in regard the Notes now in v≈øe are not of ≈øo long a quantity, as when the Perfect Moodes were v≈øed, the mo≈øt part of the Notes Ligatur'd, & Ligatures them≈øelues are layd a≈øide, except the Breue & Semibreue, which yet are retayned for the cau≈øes afore mentioned.

The 4 la≈øt ≈øimple notes, Minime, Crotchet, Quauer & Semiquauer are therfore not Ligable, becau≈øe they are not Mea≈øured; for the 10: Dunst. Men≈ø. Mu≈ø. cap. 16. Minime is the fir≈øt Note that Mea≈øureth (being in it ≈øelfe indiui≈øible) and the Semibreue the fir≈øt note Mea≈øured; and therefore the fir≈øt Note ligable; And for the other 3. Crotchet, Quauer, and Semiquauer, they are neither augmented nor dimini≈øhed, but keepe one continuall quantitie,

The fir≈øt 4. ≈øimple Notes
Ibidem. cap 3. Franchinus Inuented; & although part of their formes were not in the originall as now they are charactered, yet their Mea≈øures were all one: hee was al≈øo the fir≈øt that deuided the Largs into 3. Longs, and the Long into 3. Breues, and the Breue into 3. Semibreues. (further then which in tho≈øe dayes the Mea≈øure tended not) ≈øo all of them into 2. likewi≈øe; and thereby he was the fir≈øt that Inuented Perfection, and Imperfection.

The Minime
Ibidem. cap 6. Ph. Vitriaco (the Flowre of Mu≈øitians of all the world in his time) inuented, ob≈øeruing the ≈øame forme that Franchinus did, deuiding the Semibreue into 3. Minimes, and into 2. at the lea≈øt, and term'd it Prolation; but as for the Minime, not counting otherwi≈øe of it, then as of an Vnite, or a Poynt in Geometry, he reckoned it no Time, but the beginning of Time, and the very beginning of Mea≈øurable Mu≈øicke; and ≈øo in the≈øe dayes further then the Minime the Mea≈øure tends not, it being the fir≈øt and ≈øhorte≈øt Note that any Mea≈øure can begin on; as contrarywi≈øe the Large is the la≈øt and longe≈øt Note, that the voyee of man with one Breath can deliuer.

And as for our Crotchets, Quauers, & Semiquauers, I yet finde not the Inuention of them; and therefore I ≈øuppo≈øe no great heede was taken of the Inuentor, yet they were accepted vpon ≈øufferance; yet ≈øo, as that we now differ from the auntient in the naming of them, Ibidem. cap. 6. for that which wee terme our Quauer they term'd a Crotchet, & that which
we terme a Crotchet, they term'd a Semi-Minime, the halfe of our Minime, as the Semibreue is the halfe of the Breue. And the≈øe Simple and Compound Notes are they, which wee commonly call the Inward ≈øignes of Mea≈øurable Mu≈øicke.

div.head: Of Pau≈øes, or Re≈øts.
div.p: PAu≈øes, or Re≈øts are ≈øilent Characters, or an Artificiall omi≈ø≈øion of the voyce, reprae≈øenting the quantity of the Inward notes, or Signes, as they are Mea≈øured by the outward Signes, which were Inuented for 3. cau≈øes. 1. For Clo≈øes, 2. for Fuges, 3. for avoyding of Di≈øcords, and di≈øallowances.

div.head: Of Degrees.
div.p: DEgrees were inuented to expre≈ø≈øe the value of the afore≈øaid principall Notes, by a Perfect and Imperfect Mea≈øure. Perfect Mea≈øure is when all goe by 3.
Imperfect Mea≈øure when all go by 2. & Degrees are three-fold:

Glareanus Dodecach ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d. lib. 3. cap. 5. As all other things haue a Moode (≈øaith Glarean) ≈øo hath Mu≈øicke; and Modus ≈øignifieth a manner of ≈øomething to be reprae≈øented; and heere are all Notes of a Square Quadrat forme, and thereby are appropriated Largs and Longs, mea≈øured by the lea≈øt of this forme, the Breues.

Tempus ≈øignifieth a Time, Plutarch. which is ordained by order, hauing a iu≈øt Mea≈øure, ≈øet Limits & Bonds; and here is afigure or Note of a Glarean lib. 3. cap. 1. Sebald: Heyd: lib. 2. cap. 1. Rhombus or Circular forme, which we terme the Semi-breue; but the rea≈øon why the Time is appropriated to the Breue is in regard of the Perfect Mea≈øure of the Breue by this Circular Note, though in the forme it is applyed to the Semi-breue.

Prolation ≈øignifieth an extending or putting foorth; and it is of the Degrees from the fir≈øt mea≈øuring Note to the la≈øt mea≈øured, through the Perfect and Imperfect figures; vnto which terme Prolation is applyed, a Note of a Circular body, but with a Stroke, as a head ioyned to that Body, which is term'd the Minime; (which Sebald. Heyd: lib. 2. cap. 2. Gla. lib. 3. cap. 5. Minime mea≈øuring the Semi-breue) thereby comes it, that the Tearme Prolation is appropriated to the Semi-breue, as being the fir≈øt Note mea≈øured by the Prolationate, or extending Note.
And all three of the≈øe Degrees, are 2. fold, Io: Dun≈øtable Men≈øurabilis Mu≈øicae. cap. 16. Maior & Minor:

To the Glarean D ‚Ä¢ d ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ach ‚Ä¢ rd. lib. 3. cap. 6. Moode expre≈ø≈øing the perfection of it is attributed a Ternary number: thus 3.

But in the fir≈øt Age of the Inuention of this Art, it was expre≈øt by Re≈øts or Pau≈øes of their Notes, and in regard of the little v≈øe of the Moodes, and the Practicall occa≈øion of ≈øuch Re≈øts for Clo≈øes, and comming in of Fuges, they were layd a≈øide, and the≈øe numbers afore≈øaid accepted.

To Prolation, for the expre≈ø≈øing of the perfection therof is atributed a Poynt or prick, ≈øignifying the indiui≈øibility of the Mea≈øure which is placed in the mid≈øt of the Cicrcle thus ùáá or the Semicircle thus ùáä as by it pre≈øence it cau≈øeth Perfection; ≈øo by the ab≈øence thereof it cau≈øeth Imperfection; But tho≈øe ≈ølender Arti≈øts, which would haue the Ternary number ≈øignifie the Perfect Prolation, and the Binary the Imperfect, (and ≈øo onely appropriated) the afore≈øaid Authors condemne, as mo≈øt ignorant of the≈øe Mea≈øures.

Furthermore the≈øe afore≈øaid Degrees are deuided into 4. Tables, by ≈øome term'd Moodes, by others 4. Prolations, (but wrong by both for of Moodes and Prolations, there are but 2. the Great & the Le≈ø≈øe) but by the be≈øt vnder≈øtaÃÑdings,

div.p:
BVt now Practi≈øe hath ≈øo infected this Mea≈øure, e≈øpecially in the Prolation and Dimin ‚Ä¢ tion of it, that when a Perfect Arti≈øt comes to ≈øing a ≈øong of ≈øuch Practicall Charactering, (≈øuppo≈øing it to bee Character'd according to the iu≈øt Perfection and Imperfection of the Degrees) hee ≈øhall bee (almo≈øt) as far to ≈øeeke for the Mea≈øure intended, as were they that Compos'd it to ≈øeeke for the true Charactering of that Mea≈øure, they would haue expre≈øt. For that I may giue in≈øtance herein, I finde it by them thus exampl'd ùáä3 or thus ùáä3, the which indeed I mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe is the Imperfect Time, and the More Prolation; But then I demannd to what end t ‚Ä¢ nds that Ternary Number? Hereto they will an≈øwere (e≈øpecially tho≈øe who in conceyt are Ma≈øters) that it is to ≈øignifie a Triple Proportion, by which the Song before which it is ≈øet,
mu≈øt be ≈øung; and that is (≈øay they)3. to one. True; but then aske them what three to one? and they will tell you, 3. Minimes to one Semi-breue; O mo≈øt Vnproportionate Cu≈øtomable Compo≈øitors, who≈øe Art ≈øerues them not ≈øo much as to di≈øtingui≈øh Prolation from Proportion! For Prolation is, when 3. Minimes goe to one Semi-breue, and Triple Proportion is, when 3. Semi-breues to one Semi-breue, as being a Proportion of the Greater Inaquality, and (as wee terme it) Multiplicis generis, that is when a Greater Number is compar'd with a Le≈ø≈øer, and containeth the Le≈ø≈øer many Times as 3/1 6/2 9/3 &c. It is euident then, that this ≈øingle Ternary Number cannot ≈øtand for a Triple Proportion, ≈øeeing it wants a Le≈ø≈øer Number to bee compar'd with all; and be≈øide that, were there a Number adioyn'd, yet the ≈øigne of the Imperfect Time, the Perfect Prolation,
Ornitho. lib. 2. cap. 8. (and Number cannot work vpon Prolation ≈øo long as the Circle retaines the Poynt,) the Charactering of the Note in white, the breaking of the Mea≈øur'd Notes, and the Mea≈øure of a Le≈ø≈øer Quantity and Quality to the Tact, would all re≈øolue vs, 'tis no Triple Proportion.

Others then being beaten from that opinion, and yet not doubting but to hit the marke, make an≈øwer; Some, that the Number is there ≈øet to ≈øignifie, that 3. Minimes went to a Semi-Breue, in their idle conceites neuer remembring that the Poynt in the Semi-Circle ≈øignifies that ≈øufficiently: Some, that it is to ≈øignifie the Moode, not regarding that the Mea≈øure it ≈øelfe confutes them, in as much as this Ternary Number ≈øignifieth Perfection, and the Moodes in this Mea≈øure are Imperfect. And la≈øtly, Some (rather then faile) will haue it ≈øignifie Time, quite forgetting (as good Authors ob≈øerue) that 'tis the Circle which ≈øignifies it, which being broken in this Mea≈øure, makes it therefore Imperfect.

May I not then wel conclude, that ≈øeeing this Number ≈øignifieth neither Proportion, nor Prolation, nor Imperfect moods,
nor Time, 'tis but an Intruder, and by right mu≈øt be wholy left out in the Mea≈øure of the Perfect Prolation? which being graunted, I will ≈øay no more of it, as making account that it is a thing generally knowne.
The v≈øe of this Perfect Prolation is, in Seruice Diuine for I ‚Ä¢ bilees and Thanke≈øgiuings, and otherwi≈øe for Galliards in R ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ellings.

But in this Mea≈øure, I ob≈øerue another great error committed by them, which expre≈ø≈øe the Se≈øqui-altera-Proportion with 3. White Semi-breues, belike not vnder≈øtanding, that herein a White Semi-breue contaynes ‚Ä¢ . Minimes, if it be not Imperfected by a Le≈ø≈øe Note going before, or following; Yet will they (for≈øooth) haue 3. of these White Semi-breues goe to the Tyme of 2. Tacts or Strokes; whereas, in all nature of Proportions, it (contrariwi≈øe) ought to bee expre≈øt with 3. Semi-breues Denigrated, and ≈øo ≈øignifying Diminution; which then containe the quantity that they ayme at, of two Strokes in this Perfect Prolation,
VNto this perfect Prolation, there pertaines a 2. folde Diminution‚ñ™ the Greater and the Le≈ø≈øer; ≈øignified by Internall, and Externall Signes.

‚ñ™ Magir ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ de Art‚ñ™ Mu≈øica. Internall by the Denigrating or blacking of the Inward or ≈øimple White Notes without the Externall Signe, Dimini≈øhe the Tact, as much as the Externall Signe it ≈øelfe of the Great Diminution: Examples of which wee
finde Diuers, in Church Songs, Madrigalls, and ≈øuch like as thus:
And diuers others there are bothin the Perfect and Imperfect Mea≈øures, all pertayning to the Great Diminution.

The Externall Signes are tho≈øe which are ≈øet, at the beginning of Songs, and are the Characters of the Degrees, for the Dimini≈øhing of the White and Blacke Notes, by Da≈øh and Retort, in the Great and Le≈ø≈øe Motion of the Tact.
The Great Diminution and the Externall Signe to ≈øignifie it in White, is by a retort of the Semi-Circle with the Character of Prolation thus
Otherwi≈øe ioyning the Externall and the Internall Signes together, 'tis thus ≈øignified,

Whereas the coÃÑmon practi≈øe (in Compo≈øition for Church S ‚Ä¢ ngs, Mad ‚Ä¢ igalls, Pa≈øtoralls, Ballads, &c.) charactereth this Diminution with denigrated Notes, and the Outward ≈øigne by the Ternary Number thus:
THey ≈øeeme to drawe their Rea≈øons (as ≈øome Ma≈øters haue affirm'd) from the 3. ≈øwift feete in Poetry, Trochaeus, Iambus and Tribrachius, in regard of the Notes that are Dimini≈øhed.

But then why it ≈øhould bee apply'd more to this Diminution then to the Perfect Prolation I ≈øee no Rea≈øon at all; by cau≈øe howe're the Tact of this Diminution be of a ≈øwifter Motion, yet the Mea≈øures are all one in the diuiding of the Semi-breue, according to tho≈øe feete. As 1. Trochaeus, which is one long and the other ≈øhort, a Semi-breue and a Minime. 2. for Iambus, which by way of Retort to the former is one ≈øhort and the other long, a Minime and a Semi-breue. 3. for Tribrachius, which is three ≈øhort, the Semi-breue diuided into 3. Minimes; which diui≈øion (≈øay they) pertaines only to the Diminution and not to the Perfect Prolation; How beit many meane Practitioners are able to contrary that, and they who aright vnder≈øtand Poetry, and Mu≈øicke‚ñ™ ≈øhall be Iudges, who knowe the Mea≈øure to bee all one, and the differences of the Motion to bee according to each Rule, or according to the di≈øcretion of them that Sing, or Reade them.

But the matter here we chiefly ≈øtand vpon is, that the Ternary Number ought vtterly to be reiected, as hauing no manner of intere≈øt either in the Perfect Prolation, or the Diminutions therof: The Perfect Prolation we ≈øpake of before; and now for the Diminution thus I ≈øay, that if by their Trochaick rea≈øon they will bring this Ternary Number in, to ≈øignifie
this Diminution, they may as well, yea they mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily, to euery diui≈øion of the Semi-breue, (which may bee as diuers, as is the Compo≈øers Inuention) ≈øet a ≈øeuerall Character to ≈øignifie it, and their applications of it to the feete, by which it is Mea≈øured: But what a confu≈øion would that be to the Performer, (be≈øides the euidence of their ridiculous ignorance) to charge each Diui≈øion with a particular Character, when only the Externall and Internall Signes ≈øet at the beginning of Harmonyes are thereto ≈øufficient? And if it bee vnnece≈ø≈øary to Charactere all, I ≈øee as little rea≈øon that they ≈øhould Charactere any one: Or if yet they needs‚ñ™ will, that one be Charactered, then let them ≈øhow me, why the Mea≈øure of the≈øe other feete, which belong to the Diui≈øion of the Imperfect Prolation and the Diminutions therof, (as Spondaeus, Pyrrychius, Anapae≈øtus, Bacchius, Antib ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ chius, &c.) ≈øhould not a≈øwell be Character'd by them, as the≈øe that belong to the diui≈øion of the Perfect Prolation, and the Diminutions of it. For if they hold that a thing needle≈ø≈øe and ≈øuperfluous to be done in a ca≈øe ≈øo common and obuious: the con≈øequence will be altogether as good again≈øt this their Poeticall, phanta≈øticall Charactring with the Ternary Number.

But ≈øee how one errorbegets another; It is that which I haue ob≈øerued as a mo≈øt gro≈ø≈øe Ab≈øurditie in the pricking of the Internall Signes of this Diminution, and yet is to be found among tho≈øe, whome our Vulgar Practitioners account approued Ma≈øters, & in that opinion haue followed their Vn-art-like Example; which is, the ≈øetting of it with a White Minime and a Crotchet, and the Tact charactered with the afore≈øaid Ternary Number; as thus

Their Apologie (vpon exception taken) prooued
like their en≈øample, both fond, and ≈øencele≈ø≈øe; to witt, that they might Character the Sounds in what forme it plea≈øed them, and needed not to be bound to follow the Lawes and Rules of Art, which they found were herein wholy again≈øt them.

THe Le≈ø≈øer Diminution, (which is vulgarly call'd Morley lib. 1. fol. 15. Diminution of Diminution, or the Double Diminution of the Perfect Prolation) is the ≈øwifte≈øt Motion that any Tune it Compo≈øed of vnder this Mea≈øure, as Country Daunces, Bran'≈ø ‚Ä¢ s, Volt ‚Ä¢ s, Courant ‚Ä¢ s, & ≈øuch like: And it like wi≈øe we find character'd, to ≈øignifie the Tact of it, with the Ternary Number, which is yet of all the re≈øt the greate≈øt Ab≈øurdity: For herein there are ≈øixe Notes Mea≈øured to one Tact, (whereas afore but 3.) and Their Ternary Number is made to ≈øignifie no le≈ø≈øe then Perfect Prolation, Great Diminution, & Le≈ø≈øe Diminution, and all vpon the bare and groundle≈ø≈øe warrant of Common Practi≈øe, which ≈øay they, hath ≈øo receiu'd it, & therefore they v≈øe it.

But what a confu≈øion will this be when they haue a Song or Tune compo≈øed of all the≈øe Tacts, (as diuers there are in v≈øe for Maskes and Reuells) and ≈øhall finde but onely one Character to expre≈ø≈øe all Motions? how can that worke be perform'd in his proper nature, except the Compo≈øer ≈øhall either Demon≈øtrate by a Canon what his meaning is, or him≈øelfe per≈øonally be there to explaine his Forme intended? Therefore the Authors of our Art, fore≈øeeing the Diuer≈øities (√†nd there by the Ab≈øurdityes) which heerein would be inuented concerning the Diminutions of the Tact, agreed vpon certaine Rules and Characters together, to Demon≈øtrate euery particular Motion by, of what kinde of Diuision ≈øoeuer the‚ñ™ Tact was. But now in regard that tho≈øe Canons and Proportionate Rules are out of v≈øe, I ≈øee no rea≈øon why wee ≈øhould v≈øe their Characters, but rather be led by that Rule, where of now in the≈øe dayes our practi≈øe
con≈øi≈øts, which is the Circular Rule, and by which this le≈ø≈øer Diminution of the Perfect Prolation (the Internall Notes being Denigrated) is thus Charactered.

As for any motion of Tact ≈øwister then this Le≈ø≈øer Diminution if there ≈øhould bee need thereof, it ≈øhould be either thus Charactered

div.head: TO THE VVELL DISPOSED TO READE, AND to the merry di≈øpo≈øed to Sing.
div.p:
AMong≈øt other liberall Arts, Mu≈øicke for her part, hath alwayes beene as liberall, in be≈øtowing her melodious gifts, as any one what≈øoeuer, and that in ≈øuch rare manner, for diuer≈øitie: and ample mea≈øure, for multiplicity, as more cannot be expected, except it were more then it is re≈øpected: yet in this kind onely, it may ≈øeeme ≈øomewhat niggardly and vnkind, in neuer (as yet) publikely communicating, but alwayes priuately retaining, and as it were, enuying to all, this more familiar mirth and iocund melodie. But it may bee Mu≈øicke hath hitherto beene defectiue in this vaine, becau≈øe this vaine indeed, hath hitherto been defectiue in Mu≈øicke: and therefore, that fault being now mended, this kind of Mu≈øicke al≈øo is now commended to all mens kind acceptation. This did I willingly vndertake, and haue ea≈øily effected, that all might equally pertake of that which is ≈øo generally affected. Catches ≈øo generally affected (I take it) quia non ≈øuperant captum, becau≈øe they are ≈øo con≈øonant to all ordinarie mu≈øicall capacity‚ñ™
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
being ≈øuch indeed, as all ≈øuch who≈øe loue of Mu≈øicke exceedes their ≈økill, cannot but commend, ≈øuch al≈øo, as all ≈øuch, who≈øe ≈økill in Mu≈øicke, exceedes their loue of ≈øuch ≈øleight and light fancies, cannot either contemne or condemne. Good Art in all, for the more mu≈øicall‚ñ™ good mirth and melodie for the more Iouiall, ≈øweet harmonie, mixed with much varietie, and both with great facilitie. Harmony to plea≈øe, varietie to delight, facilitie to inuite thee. Some toyes yet mu≈øicall, without ab≈øurdity, Some very mu≈øicall, yet plea≈øing without difficulty, light, but not without mu≈øickes delight, Mu≈øickes plea≈øantnes, but not without ea≈øines, what ≈øeemes old, is at lea≈øt renewed, Art hauing reformed what plea≈øing tunes iniurious time and ignorance had deformed. The onely intent is to giue generall content, compo≈øed by Art to make thee di≈øpo≈øed to mirth. Accept therefore kindly, what is done willingly, and publi≈øhed onely, to plea≈øe good Company

div.p: SEcundae cogitationes are euer (they ≈øay) meliores; and why may not then ≈øecundae Cantiones be as well dulciores? I pre≈øume they are ≈øo, and that makes me re≈øume this vaine, with hope that I ≈øhall not con≈øume in vaine my labour herein.

For fir≈øt, the kinde acceptation of the former Impre≈øsion is as a new invitation to this latter Edition, though not of the ≈øame things, yet of things of the ≈øame condition; full of the ≈øame delectation, made to plea≈øe, as the other were; to plea≈øe I ≈øay, and that with as much ea≈øe, as the other; made truely Mu≈øicall with Art by my correction, and yet plaine, and capable with ea≈øe, by my direction.

Againe, Bonum qu√≤ communius e√≤ melius, we know; and I know no rea≈øon, why incundum, qu√≤ communius, ≈øhould not be as well iucundius: Now then the nature of the≈øe (call them as you will) in regard of their facilitie and ≈øo their capabilitie is more communicable, then any other kinde of Mu≈øicke‚ñ™ and in this re≈øpect more
commendable; and will be I am ≈øure more acceptable, becau≈øe the things which many heretofore haue priuately ioyed in, may now by this meanes, publikely be inioyed.

Neither, can he, that is the mo≈øt able Mu≈øition ≈øay, but that of the≈øe mo≈øt men, almost all men are capable, that are not altogether immu≈øicall: Neither can He, that is mo≈øt ≈øpitefull ≈øay, but they are very delighfull, I, and ≈øome way gainfull too; (yet more painefull to me, I am ≈øure, then gainefull.) But, though there bee but little to bee gotten by them, yet pittie were it, ≈øuch Mirth ≈øhould be forgotten of vs; And therefore to make an end, I ≈øay no more but‚ÄîSiquid noui≈øti dulcius i≈øtis.
